reviewText: i loved this movie. i had not seen it before and really enjoyed it. the transfer is good and so is the sound. no exgtras, which was dissapointing. it is a story of two lovers that get married and then find due to her fathers and the new husbands jobs they can not reveal the marriage. just an old movie with a good plot and good acting. as i said, i loved it.
Title: The Secret Bride

reviewText: Yay! This is exactly the kind of thing I like: Classy dames, smart lawyers, fun mystery, GORGEOUS clothes. A very pretty Barbara Stanwyck and sexy cool Warren William star in "The Secret Bride", a second-tier Warner Brothers pic from 1934, but second-tier then blows first-tier now out of the balcony, so well worth a closer look.Stanwyck is Ruth Vincent, Governor's daughter and in the opening of our film brand new bride to Warren's District Attorney Robert Sheldon. A funny thing happens on the way to tell the Governor, and the newlyweds find themselves in the center of a rapidly expanding scandal involving bribes, frames, and murder. Will our fearless duo solve the mystery, save Dad's job, and totter off into a lifetime of wedded bliss? And more importantly, where does Barbara get her fabulous hats?Though it's Stanwyck on the cover of the DVD, she plays second fiddle to Warren William, who gets much more screen time and walks away with the film. Ladies, they don't make them like this anymore: Suave, sophisticated, utterly in control, conceding battle after battle until he finally wins the war. When the entire state cabinet demands his resignation he coolly informs Stanwyck "They can demand my resignation until they run out of words" and gets right back to work. I love it.Like I said, not a five star classic (for one thing, at 64 minutes, a bit short) but a fun rainy day film. I don't know if it's worth buying, but a rental definitely and rating:GRADE: B+It's not out on video, but if you ever come across Warren's "Lone Wolf Spy Hunt" or "The Case of the Lucky Legs" RECORD THEM. Those are five star.
summary: "I've smashed your career." "It isn't smashed yet."
Title: The Secret Bride

reviewerName: John H. McCarthy "Two Degrees In Be-Bop, A Ph...
reviewText: It's always nice when you view a film that exceeds your expectations. In John Stangeland's generally excellent biography of Warren,WARREN WILLIAM: Magnificent Scoundrel Of Pre-Code Hollywood, the author considers the film "a forgettable programmer," "mere product" and "a waste of (the) two stars."  His main complaint seems to revolve around the plot, although many will find it's themes quite contemporary.  Warren plays an Attorney General who marries Barbara Stanwyck, the daughter of his boss, the governor.  Before they can break the news to daddy, a scandal erupts accusing the governor of selling a pardon to a convicted financier, who soon afterwards commits suicide. Barbara convinces new hubby Warren to keep the marriage secret since as Attorney General he has no choice but to investigate the accusations, and news of their marriage would compromise the situation. I found the story to be quite enjoyable and even after viewing hundreds of mysteries the film kept me baffled as to who was behind all the shenanigans, especially when the character who I figured was the obvious suspect was....well, I'm not going to ruin it for you!  Youngsters will be surprised to find that political corruption, shady financiers and sensational journalism wasn't invented on their watch. The supporting cast of Warner Brothers regulars (Glenda Farrell, Grant Mitchell, Henry O'Neill, Douglas Dumbrille) were all great in their roles, and I was impressed by the innovative direction of prolific William Dieterle.  Be on the lookout for a great shot filmed through the back of a radio! Although it's probably true that Warren, Barbara and Dieterle weren't fond of their assignments, you'd never guess it by the excellent character portrayals and direction. Running a snappy 64 minutes, THE SECRET BRIDE is a good example of the truth to the old cliche "they don't make 'em like they used to."  Anyone fond of '30's movies, the actors, the director, or mystery films will not be disappointed......(3 and 1/2 stars)If you like this, try these GREAT sets of Pre-Code Hollywood, some featuring the stars:Forbidden Hollywood, Volume One,Forbidden Hollywood, Volume Two,Forbidden Hollywood, Volume Five,Forbidden Hollywood, Volume Six,Frank Capra: The Early Collection,Perry Mason Mysteries: The Original Warner Brothers Movies Collection
Title: The Secret Bride
